adverb.description: Toward or in a lower place or position, especially to or on the ground or another surface.
examples: she looked down
the sun started to go down
he put his glass down
he swung the ax to chop down the tree
she flicked the switch up and down

adverb.description: To or at a lower level of intensity, volume, or activity.
examples: keep the noise down
the panic was dying down
at night it would cool down

adverb.description: In or into a weaker or worse position, mood, or condition.
examples: the scandal brought down the government
he was down with the flu
taking down notes
I just write down whatever comes into my head

adverb.description: (with reference to partial payment of a sum of money) made initially or on the spot.
examples: pay $500 down and the rest at the end of the month

adverb.description: (of sailing) with the current or the wind.
(of the ball or a player in possession) not in play, typically because forward progress has been stopped.

preposition.description: From a higher to a lower point of (something)
examples: up and down the stairs
tears streaming down her face
astrologers down the ages

adjective.description: Directed or moving toward a lower place or position.
examples: the down escalator
click on the down arrow
he's been so down lately

adjective.description: (of a computer system) temporarily out of action or unavailable.
examples: sorry, but the computer's down

adjective.description: Supporting or going along with someone or something.
examples: you got to be down with me
she was totally down for a selfie
“You going to the movies?” “Yo, I'm down.”

verb.description: Knock or bring to the ground.
examples: 175 enemy aircraft had been downed
he struck Slater on the face, downing him
he downed a six-pack

noun.description: A chance for a team to advance the ball, ending when the ball carrier is tackled or the ball becomes out of play. A team must advance at least ten yards in a series of four downs in order to keep possession.

examples: there had been more downs than ups during his years at the company

noun.description: A feeling or period of unhappiness or depression.
examples: everyone gets their downs, their depressive periods

proper noun.description: One of the six counties of Northern Ireland, formerly an administrative area; chief town, Downpatrick.

phrases: To be fair, we were down on Episode III from the outset.
Before I agreed to join Wigan, everyone was down on me and having a go because I was even considering it, he says.
Over the years, readers may have gained the idea that the police in general, and London's Met police in particular, had a down on demonstrations.
I am going to be accused of having a down on female drivers.
I really don't understand why they are so down on her.
origin: Old English dūn hill (related to Dutch duin dune), perhaps ultimately of Celtic origin and related to Old Irish dún and obsolete Welsh din fort, which are from an Indo-European root shared by town.
